newsitem.title: USA: CrossRoads to use IBM component technology.
newsitem.headline: CrossRoads to use IBM component technology.

text.p: CrossRoads Software Inc said it has agreed to use IBM's component broker technology as part of an alliance between the companies.

Privately held CrossRoads, which marked its formal corporate launch in San Francisco on Thursday, is developing software products designed to link disparate business application software from multiple vendors.

The company demonstrated an early "alpha" version of its first products, which will provide integration between front-office customer interaction systems and back-office enterprise resource planning (ERP) software.

CrossRoads executives said the company is due to begin customer testing of the initial product, with Bay Networks and Hewlett-Packard Co as initial test partners, later this month. Beta testing is expected in the third quarter and general availability is due in the fourth quarter.

Katrina Garnett, founder and chief executive of CrossRoads, said the company's system was designed using Sun Microsystems Inc's Java programming technology and is made to work directly "out of the box."

The CrossRoads InterChange Server will run as a Microsoft Windows NT/BackOffice application, using Microsoft's COM and DCOM component object models as well as ActiveX to integrate application services.
The company will also use other Microsoft technology.

George Gilbert, an analyst at investment bankers Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said the market for licensing business application integration products such as CrossRoads is developing and could reach $4 billion by 2000.
The company's goal is ambitious, aiming to simplify and reduce the cost of patching together applications ranging from human resources and payroll tasks to manufacturing and financial functions.

Until now, companies operating more than one of these systems have had to create costly custom solutions to link the systems together, whereas CrossRoads aims to create a modular structure to link the programs automatically.
